Thanks for this vídeo.  Common sense adjustments agree with scentific studies. Less oil makes you adjust your throwing more to the center of the lane to hit the pocket. For a dry lanes the aim zone will be narrow and to the center ( mark 10 to 17 right hand and mark 30 to 23 left hand). Two handed throwers need more power and will follow similar aim zone release adjustments. No nightmare , a dry lane is a challenge to make adjustments for pros and amateurs alike.  Thanks and have a great bowling day.

Something that caught my attention was the comment made at ~24:20 that winter tires have less friction during summer as less surface area is touching the lane. That isn't true as friction does not depend of surface area, but only on the CoF b/w surfaces. Its not recommened to use winter tires during dry summer condition as they're much "softer" in their rubber composition (and hence wear out faster) and behave/flex much differently than their summer counterparts, resulting in poor handling generally.

I don't bowl very often but when I do I use a non-conventional method.  I have weak wrist so the normal method doesn't work well for me, what I do instead is a sort of overhand throw.  I use my 2 middle fingers and exclude the thumb and give the ball a twist using my entire arm and shoulder.  My hand starts out partially twisted to the right (I bowl right handed) and I twist it to the left.  My best game was around 192 I think, a few strikes and spares with the other shots hitting most of the pins.  Next time I go bowling I'll have to keep this video in mind as the only trick I really employed was twisting the ball and aiming for that particular spot (I don't think anyone ever told me where to aim but it's pretty intuitive).

Back in the 60's and 70's, I was a real good bowler. I had my own shoes, ball, wrist glove, and was in all the leagues, competitions, and even on the UCSB Bowling Team.  We used a solid, black rubber ball that was 16lb. That's it. I have no idea about the old, and had to adjust to each lane each tiem I bowled. I guess I'm a sports purist - don't like the DH in baseball - but all this high tech tinkering with ball and the lane seems to take some of the skill out of the game. I had to stop bowling when I was 44 due to huring my back, and I still had a 190-200 average back then. I loved bowling as a kid, since I had asthma for the first 13 years of my life, so bowling and pool were the only two sports I could play, and I became very good at both. I guess I should look up pool and billiards to see how they have messed with the "center of gravity" of those spherical shaped solid balls to enhance performance. I'm guessing no tampering with pool balls, but I would not have guessed all the engineering and maninpulation that goes into bowling today. I suppose anyone can adjust to new parameters, but I'm glad they don't use aluminum bats in the MLB. When they think they need to do it to sell tickets, they'll do it.

I,ve been bowling for most of my youth and my entire adult life. I quit about 8 years ago because our local bowling alley shut down. I tried to bowl out of town but it was to much of a hassle. Back then when I  purchased a ball, I knew what I wanted the ball to do and how I wanted it drilled. I was pretty good at bowling, with multable 300 games and 800 series games. The technology that came around over the years, made everyone a better bowler. These days it is very common to see a 175 average bowler shoot 300. The 300 game is pretty common all over the U.S. For every 300 bowled in a sanctioned league makes you eligible to buy a gold 300 ring a the market rate of gold. They are fairly expensive. I bowled my first 300 when I was 20 years old and back then, the 300 game was rare so the gold rings were at no charge to the bowler. That is the one that is very special to me because It cost me nothing. every one after that, I had to pay for it if I wanted to. Bowling in a league was like going to church. You would see each other once a week.  I have made many friends as a result of bowling but since the closure I hardly see the people I used to bowl with anymore. It was a wonderful time in my life. Oh and by the way your video was outstanding. The best video to date regarding how technology has evolved in the sport.

I feel like I need to throw this out there. I've been working at a bowling alley for 5.5 years. Most bowling alleys cater to public bowlers (who either don't know or don't care about oil being present on the lane). Most facilities will cut costs on oil and only oil on league days or about 10 lanes each day for league bowlers to practice on. If you're going on a friday or saturday night hoping for any oil, don't get your hopes up. Oil dries out, balls soak up oil as they go as well so you're probably getting some pretty bare ass lanes. With that being said if anyone is trying to get into bowling and want oil to practice on, any days that have leagues or mornings in general there's usually at least SOME lanes prepared with oil.

With that muscle and that light weight ball pins were still bouncing around when the gate came down.  This also resulted in the highest scores ever for me, one who only bowls about once in ten years. Each game was over 200 for the four games played.  The light weight ball moving at relatively high velocity provide such a high impulse to the pins they tended to bonce around such a long time as to knock many pins over. The ball was on the floor popping and spitting and billowing black sooty smoke.
I laid down next to the ball and with two of the biggest breath so I could take I blew the flames out and carefully picked up the ball and threw it out the second story window of the room I was in I was coughing out chunks of soot for two weeks after that.
The whole second floor of the house had smoke damage and I was to embarrassed to tell the owner often house who was my friends firefighter father.

Back when we were bowling on Saturday nights as teenager nobody we knew could throw a ball hook. After seeing my wife do it I wanted to learn. First step get a proper ball and then practice practice practice. For a couple months we were going I was getting tips from the pro at the alley. So one particular Saturday my wife and I practice and then played a game like we normally did. This time I actually beat her. We probably had told a hundred games plus and I never even came close to beating her. Now she is mad and I never realized how big of a sore loser she was.

Of course I'm teasing her now and she said we are going to play again I wasn't really trying is what she said to me. Second game the same outcome as the first one. Now she is beyond the head. This happened about 14 years ago. To this day we have not gone bowling at all.

Up until the mid 1980s, the American Bowling Congress would not sanction oil conditions that were anything but uniform across the lane.  That's why a 1985 average in 1980 corresponds to about 220- 225 average today (league bowling, that is).  Of course another part of that equation is the difference in balls, too.  As a relevant point of reference, today lanes are oiled with about 20ml of oil.  In 1980, that amount was about 2-3ml.  That's a sign of how much more powerful balls are today.

7:35: It's amazing how accurate some things are that humans do. Modern "shooter" video games are a good example of this. When I was first getting serious about my aim, I started doing things like measuring my sensitivity, how big targets were in respect to mouse movements, etc, and it's astonishing how fine and accurate those movements need to be. Even with a very low sensitivity, it's not uncommon for a person size target at a medium distance to require mouse movements more accurate than a half a millimeter to hit the shot. And considering that this often all unfolds in under a second between noticing the person, snapping the crosshairs on them and then shooting, it's an astonishing thing.

I was familiar with some of these concepts, and i do throw curving balls, but this is much more detail than i knew. I usually try to aim for roughly the kind of curve shown here, but adapt to the conditions of the lane as i discover it through the first series. I've had 3 games in the 220s with standard house balls, and i suspect the lane conditions were very good coupled with a decent amount of luck on top of good shape those days.
I don't bowl competitively or in any league, so i suspect my scores are dominated by the dice of public bowling lane oiling and the state of the house balls that day. In general I've found low friction (too much oil or smooth balls) to be my main problem. Though i did once bowl on an almost dry lane, which was horrible and no matter how calmly i tried to spin the ball it always went in the left gutter. When there's way too much oil in the "dry zone", i move the initial position of my curve further right, and possibly even slow down the speed of my ball. In the other case of a dry oiled section i move longer left and throw harder or put less spin on the ball.

I waited until the last day of registration to sign up for a Phys Ed class my freshman year of college. The only class left was bowling. I thought, "Crap! Bowling is so LAME!!!"

It was a FASCINATING class!!! We didn't throw a bowling ball for the first month. We learned about history, physics, friction coefficient, physiology, even the wood they make the lanes and pins out of. If it's offered at your school, I highly recommend it.

As a Bowling Center mechanic since the early 80's I can tell you ABC ( American Bowling Congress) allowed  us to change the way we oiled the lanes, it use to be no more than 3 units difference between each board of the lane or the award score did not pass and you had to oil the lane so far down.  They changed it to allow us to do shorter oil patterns and then quit checking altogether after award scores were shot.  Once they quit checking everyone changed the oil patterns to a "blocked shot" which is usually hardly any oil on first 10 boards of the lane then a large wall in the middle of lane so the ball rolls along the wall to the end of the oil then hooks into the pocket.  It is like rolling your ball on a railroad track to the pocket.  They still use blocked shots almost everywhere today.  A blocked shot makes it super easy to score high, yes the bowling ball technology has increased since the 80's.  I will tell you this , put out a difficult pattern where it is more a crown shot with no more than 3 units of oil difference between each board and most bowlers averages will drop by as much as 30 pins a game. In the end making the game easier was the death of the sport as most bowling alleys have closed in this area, there use to be 4 more than there is today and league bowling is at a all time low even before covid.

I disagree with Pete.  If that was the standard (dry) we would all adapt to that.  When you put  different oil patterns down for different skill level of bowlers, you separate the aware bowlers from the  rest.  You also make it harder for lower level bowlers to move up.  To be very good, you have to be able to read the lanes, and you have to match your ball to the lane conditions plus your style of delivery, or roll.  It's very complicated and like any pro sport, takes many support people and coaches to make you successful.  You have to be consistent and able to adapt from shot to shot.  My high score; 289.  My average when I left bowling; 172  Not great, but it took a lot of work and bowling 4-5 times a week and some lucky advice from some good people and a lane pro.  My ball; Dick Weber 5 star. That's also why pros will have strike and spare balls. Strike balls are meant to try to curve and hit the six degree angle, while there are quite a few balls that have a perfectly spherical core, so they curve very little. Carry down is why I don't bowl anymore.
Game 1) 200+
Game 2) 175-195
Game 3) 160-180

Game one, there's a good shot and you're rockin' the pocket and any miss can be chalked up to human error.

Halfway through the 2nd game, the left lane is 2 boards light, the right lane is 3 boards heavy but if you miss one board right it hooks like a banshee and one board left slides through the hook zone. The worst part is that your pair isn't even done changing yet and the left and right are going in different directions for some reason.

Game three, at this point you just hope for "good count" on your spares because you're not even sniffing the pocket. By the time the abomination of game three is over, you're so beyond frustrated that you swear you're going to quit bowling. Then one day, you do.

5:38 Specifically, in the conventional bowling score format, to score a perfect game one would need to bowl 12 strikes, not 10, in a row, including three strikes in the tenth (final) frame. Recently, a new format was introduced to facilitate viewer interest in International events such as the Olympics or World Championships, called the "international format." This format relegates each frame as independent of each other, not relying on previous frame(s) results to augment a current frame score, such as a carryover spare or strike(s). In this case, only 10 strikes is needed to record a 300 game.

Bowling, like Sumo, is the only perfect sport. They depend only on the effort and technique of the athlete, there is no one right technique, there is no perfect athlete, there is a perfect score possible.
This was borne out to me some years ago when I heard on NPR (so you know it must be true, since it is fact based story-telling) the following:
In a mid-western bowling league a particular athlete, in league play, had thrown 11 strikes. As he was getting ready for the last roll, and before the pins were even set, there was a power outage. He was given the choice, come back the next day after power was restored and roll the last ball. Or, the pins would be set by hand, all the artificial lighting available would be used to light the lane and he could take the part roll then and there. He took the latter and scored a perfect game getting a 12th strike.

WOW .... had to stop before half way through. I get that this is an explanation to noobs, but really this is bad. I started bowling about 1975 ish, and continued through the next 20+ years. Rubber, plastic, urethane and resin balls. I was a season away from a PBA card until I popped  the tendon in my ring finger. I was a cranker, ala PDW, Amletto, Mark Roth, and after my injury was still at 18-20 mph and 25+ revs. I knew friction coefficients of every one of the 20+balls I used, their drilling patterns and the effect of each one. I wont name brands, but I still have Storm equipment. What the advanced bowler can do vs the once in a while bowler is night and day. I get ragged on that I still have my own equipment and refuse to use house shoes and balls. Yeah my span and pitch angles have changed, but this video is equating success to equipment, just like Ebonite did with their first resin balls. This game is as complex as any other, try reading an oil pattern, then choosing the right balls, lines, break points, and the carry down through the game. Yes by creating an angle you increase the the amount of contact are, but it is your release, alignment and understanding of your game that will help you. No I did not get my card, my injury (at age 24) has never healed and I can not lift the way I want to. Oh yeah there is this thing called lift, that is where you use your fingers to create both forward and angular rotation on the ball. YOU DONT FREAKING SPIN THE BALL!!!!! YOU LIFT THROUGH THE BALL TO CREATE ROTATIONAL FORCES AND USE THE WEIGHT BLOCK, COVER STOCK AND SPEED TO CHANGE DIRECTION / ANGLE!  PDW and Chris Barns and on a different level than 99% of us. I Idolized PDW and spent years practicing and learning the game and still can not come close. This video is over simped. It is not just the ball, but the driller, the coach, the player and the skills of that player to read lanes and adjust their equipment and body. Hell I watched PDW win a tourney with a Bobcat drilled 3/4 finger (hook 3, length 5, weight block: 3 piece) to blow out a player with a 10+ hook ball, Rhino black (dull urethane, hook potential of 6-7,if I recall correctly, 3 piece weight block drilled3/4-1/2.) What does that tell you? IT IS ABOUT THE PERSON AND NOT THE GEAR.

I was a mediocre bowler, or so I thought, for many years as I knew virtually nothing about bowling balls. My now ex-wife & mother-in-law bowled leagues with my wife bowling 3 with my brother’s wife. She was a pretty good bowler at 189 av. My brother around 160. I only bowed recreationally with house balls and about 130 av. I got a brand new 15 lb bowling ball for Xmas from my mother-in-law. It was a plastic ball & THE HOLES WERE ALREADY DRILLED! I didn’t know. My wife & mother-in-law obviously DIDN’T want me to bowl better than them. So my brother talked my ex-wife & I into bowing in a mixed league. Four weeks in I’m averaging 136. So brother asks why I’m so bad. Told him how I acquired my balk & that I had to use stickum to even hold onto it. He says you’ve been set up to be bad at bowling & says let’s go to the pro shop. I bought a new 16 lb synthetic Rhino & had it drilled to fit. First game the next week I rolled my highest, a 585 series, and only bowled under 600 twice the rest of the league. My highest was a 656 and my av was 1&3. Then I broke my arm & didn’t bowl for a year. Then reactive resin came out. Bought one. OMG! Now I was bowling hi 600s regularly and bowled my first perfect game in a small tournament. Two months after the perfect game I nearly died in a quad motorcycle accident in the CA desert. This was 1996. Haven’t bowled since. 😞

My league average was 175, but at a house that was well-known for inconsistent oil conditions because oil was still applied manually with an industrial hand-operated floor polisher. I learned about consistent and extreme oil patterns at a tournament where my best game was 289 and there were several 300 games in the group, and I even threw a 300 in practice, then it was back to 175. I found that I could not control the ball as well if it hooked too much, so I stayed away from the new materials and used a Columbia "white-dot" to keep my hook down to 12-15 boards.
Once I bowled a ball and got a strike until one bounced back up und landed it was cool but annoying

Living in Thailand for almost 20 years I stopped bowling because all (I mean «ALL») the bowling lanes in Thailand are just 100% entirely covered with oil from left to right - from start to end. Thais never understood and probably will never understand how to oil a bowling lane. Additionally the area where the player fires his shot off is sticky like there was glue on it. No chance to slide on the leather and stop on the rubber part of your bowling shoes. I was far from being a pro bowler before I moved to Thailand but played an average of around 180 with a top score of 247. The thai bowling centers made me stop playing completely although I still got some balls and shoes sitting in my storage room... very sad :(

Funny, I learned all this stuff (plus much, much more) about bowling when I was around 7 or 8. It was one of the few things I took seriously as a kid and by the time high school came, I was #2 in our district and #4 in the state. I was the backup for our team in regionals but was also offered substantial grants to go play for colleges. Hell, I was even told (by a couple professional bowlers I knew back then) to register in a preliminary PBA open to take a crack at professional competition. I'd maintained a 220+ average at more than 3 alleys for over a year straight.

Most of my best memories thus far took place in one of the 5 bowling alleys I frequented growing up. Hell, one of my first jobs was at a bowling alley. My very last match in my school let me finish my last game with 10 strikes in a row. My 11th ball gave me this really random, fucked up split (I believe it was a 4-10) and I screwed it up pretty good, despite getting the highest game of the entire match. There was a all crowd watching me and everyone else in the alley stopped and watched me by the 7th frame. Each time I threw the ball, I'd come back and see another 40-50 people standing behind me. By the time the 10th frame rolled around, you could hear a mouse fart in the alley and there was a crowd of around 400-500 people watching.

I may have missed my chance to try anything like this professionally, but now I'm just happy to be able to share the game with my kids.

Great episode on bowling. Do tennis next! There is soooo much to talk about with tennis in regards to spin and friction. In addition to topspin, tennis players routinely use backspin, side-spin, and spiral-spin as well. If you really want to have some fun, try explaining the physics of the kick serve. This is a serve in tennis where the ball curves through the air in one direction, dips down, and then when it hits the ground it bounces in the opposite direction!!! Then there's the different court surfaces, hardcourt, clay, and grass, and how each spin response to those. If the surface has more friction then topspin will make the ball kick up higher. Then for backspin the ball can react differently depending on it's incoming velocity. If a ball hit with backspin is slow (in the horizontal direction) then when it hits the ground it stops short and bounces higher, but... if a ball hit will backspin is traveling faster then it will skid and stay low. Tennis players know and use all of these spins and reactions off the court to their advantage . Pro tennis players are masters of spin and knowing the effects of spin on a ball. It's all part of the game. For more on the physics of tennis I recommend the book The Physics and Technology of Tennis by Broady, Cross, and Lindsey, and the updated version Technical Tennis: Racquets, Strings, Balls, Courts, Spin, and Bounce by Cross, and Lindsey.

The relation of sport and technology is fascinating. You ask, in the video, if the new tech makes one better. What it actually does is make the scores higher; that is, makes it less essential to be precise. And, of course, when that gets out of hand, the sport has to change something else to restore the need for skill (such as the oil pattern in sport and pro bowling). I suppose that the tech does make for a more accessible game .. it is easier to tune the game to lower skill levels which allows beginners to have fun and see improvements before moving on to the tougher playing fields. And it is possible to have fun with friends at a bowling alley with little training at all.

Vertasium: so for a casual bowler, it's easy to think throwing it directly in the middle is the best way to go. However, that usually ends up in a split so the best approach is to rather hit the pins a little bit to the side. More specifically, hit at around board 17.5 to hit pins 1, 3, 7, 9 to create a domino effect. So this is obviously tough because you need to aim for a spot smaller than a dim. However if you hit it from the side, that then widens the target significantly. To do this, you need to curve the ball so it hits the pins at an angle of 6 degrees. This is done easily by utilising the oil laid out on the first 3/4 of the track to rotate the ball fast enough so that when it gets to the unsoiled final 1/4 of the track, it hooks dramatically. However, you need to take into account the displacement of the oil due to bowling balls interacting with the oil as well as the oil layouts of certain tracks. You need to adapt to the circumstances, never throwing it too far outward or too close inward to avoid any unwanted friction discrepancies. If you want to, you can study the common oil layouts of bowling tracks all named after animals. You also should take into account the inner weights of a bowling ball by estimating its radius of giration and then its moment of inertia. You can estimate this more effectively by letting the ball spin on a cushion of air until it settles on is heavier side. Once you calculate this, you want to throw on a spin somewhere between the minimum and maximum moment of inertia. This is made easier if you get a manufactured bowling ball with rad-4 cores becausw of its prwferred spin axis. Its also important to account of the surface material of your bowling ball. The top 5 most influential factors of a ball curve is the amplitude of surface roughness, the coefficient of friction in an oiled lane, surface roughness by spacing. The coefficient of friction with a dry lane, and how quickly the ball surface absorbs oil. This is why its important to stay up to date with manufactured bowling ball technology as it could mean the difference between winning and losing. But remember, the direction of your ball can still be impacted by hundeds of other factors like the colour of your ball. So as long as you keep that in mind, you will be able to throw the perfect bowling ball.

Should report on different oil patterns those machines can lay down. If you like to hook the ball, there is the phenomenon of the crown pattern where the oil thickness gets progressively less as you move from the centre to the gutter. Effectively, the further you throw the ball towards the gutter, the harder it hooks back. A ball pulled inside of target hooks less and still hits the intended target. Really great for the ego.

In Germany 9-Pin Bowling is actually called Kegeln. The sport is named after the shape of the pins, it would directly translate to coneing. In Kegeln the balls also do not have holes in them. It is also not the usual practice to have your own ball for Kegeln, even ambitious amateurs use the balls from the lane. Kegeln lanes most of the time are found in the backrooms of bars, so called Kneipen (German beer halls). The mechanical system to get the pins upright again is also different, in Kegeln the pins are attached to strings which is more efficient considering space but more prone to tangling, I have never witnessed a game in which the pins didnt need to be untangled at least once.

So in Germany only the american version is called bowling and the german version is called Kegeln. The american version became popular only in more recent years, so starting in the mid approx. 1985. Kegeln is still more widely spread, but you can find Bowling alleys in every slightly bigger German city nowadays.

Years ago, at my office, we had a league bowler who seemed an absolute marvel to the uninitiated. There was a bowling alley across the street, and once in a while after work we'd all go over, ostensibly to bowl, but mostly to watch him.

To his coworkers, he appeared as good or better than the pros on TV, and newcomers would always ask why he himself wasn't up on the screen. He'd laugh and explain how we were all bowling on a "house shot" - i.e., a recreational oil pattern - and that house shots were easier to score on. He said this was no secret, that most regular bowlers were aware of the difference between patterns used for customer play - even league play - and those used for pro play. He assured us that if he had to bowl on pro patterns, we'd soon see the difference between him and the pros.

I think it was pretty classy of him to be honest. I'm afraid that if I had been he, I'd have been tempted to describe myself as an undiscovered Don Carter.

Today I learned something

"When we make bowling balls we always start in the center"
Wow, never would have guessed. :-/

What I didn't guess was the totally asymmetrical and strangely shaped interior weights, interesting. I wonder how different the balls with radically different shapes inside feel and operate.

"I didn't know they intentionally put oil on the lanes"
Really? Fowl badly just once and you very much will know it, in an extremely physical way. It is very embarrassing, as anyone who sees it, even three lanes over, will spontaneously burst into momentary uncontrollable laughter. It is very hard not to. Think of what most everyone does when learning to water ski. It looks pretty much exactly like that, but with a hard arresting surface, which makes it infinitely funnier than the beginning skier, which really isn't funny, at all.

My guess is that that oiling pattern gets ruined during the day, with balls carrying the thicker oil to the intended thinner areas...just a guess. I remember my aunt, who was very good, not that far from a 200 average, say that her average improved a LOT when accurate pattern oiling was coming into its own. This must happen to at least some degree as you can see oil on the ball when it returns, so at a minimum the oil is being depleted, especially if everyone is bowling on the same line.

If you hit the headpin square on it is actually the antithesis of a "perfect strategy". The 'big four' split is not the hardest one to clear, but it is certainly hard enough. Obviously percentages vary with skill, but they aren't particularly high for anyone. I've done it several times, but equating to pool, a completed intended four railer occurs for me about as often, one time in a whole major slew of attempts (how's that for quantifying?), in a game situation.

I used to throw pretty hard, probably much too hard, but it was always satisfying to hear those strikes that sound like a single impact and basically just explode off the boards. Kind of like a crack/bang sound, and visually very satisfying.

Man, that was a wide strike at 7:10 and they usually look about like that. This is what people would call luck (doesn't exist) but is actually just the tails of the bell curve, a few sigma out. GREAT choice of shot for that point, BTW, about as marginal as it can possibly get. It is kind of like when you see a pro pool player raise their hand to say sorry, while personally thinking they will take ten more of those. Obviously in pro bowling the response is not remotely as reserved. :-/ "You wanted it, you got it" with a raised fist. Funny, I wonder what his response is the 85% of the time he hits that far out of the pocket and it doesn't fall? Maybe "You wanted it, it didn't matter?"

"And that is impossible .." Then immediately shows that it isn't. I've seen several strikes thrown on the adjacent land to the bowler's. Problem is, it's a gutter, zero, zip, nada. Personally I think you should get twenty points and the next three balls counted, as it is VERY difficult to pull off. :-) /S

The problem with curves, especially late high angle versions is that while the target is notably larger, the path is notably harder to execute accurately, so there's that.

"The determinator" LOL, the guy who named that machine has been watching too many cartoons, and probably has a good sense of humor. I like it.

Ah, you verified my oil movement idea later on. The fact that the robot lost was just stupid. All it needed was a feedback system to see the ball's impact point on each throw and modify the trajectory accordingly and it would have smashed the pro. I'm virtually certain that the robot's designers were fully aware of this phenomena from previous tests (how could they not be, really?) and purposely did not add some feedback for some reason that escapes me entirely. If I had been the engineer and known the test was coming up, I would have...probably politics of some sort, almost always is. An applied AI program today would make mince meat of that problem, given enough varying lane conditions, etc, to practice (learn) on, and just like with Casparov (or Fischer, don't remember) in chess, it would trounce the human. Hell, they drive cars better now, a vastly more difficult proposition.

You could do a video on friction alone, or at least fundamental forces, and the new discoveries of what really drive them, often not what we thought, ten or a hundred years ago.

Heh, this takes me back. I used to be a Junior Gold Bowler back about a decade ago before my family got hit with financial issues, and couldn't continue. But I will agree; bowling is simple to pick up for anyone, and simultaneously one of the most complicated precision sports (or activity to those who don't see it as a sport) in the world. There is a saying back in my league that stuck with me: You never throw the same Strike twice. Every game is different, and managing to get a perfect game is something that requires a mix of skill and luck. Throwing a perfect game is hard, but not impossible; throwing a perfect series is straight up insane. But what really drove me to bowl competitively was that your opponent wasn't the person next to you; it was the game itself. The pins are your opponent, the lane is your playing field, and the ball is all you got. Once it's released, there's nothing you can do but watch to see if it hit the mark, and pray you guessed right. Because in bowling, no one else is in control of winning or losing the game, but you.

Wow, I bowled for years and never knew these things about lanes and ball friction dynamics. And it explains why even though I could hit strikes often, by going for that 6 degree entry, how my next shots using identical motion and approach etc. didn't stay consistent. Because I wasn't adjusting to the changes in the lane condition quickly enough. Aha! Eventually, I would naturally adjust and hit more strikes again by the end of the game typically and finish really strong, but I always had lulls in the middle of the game where I was just doing "o.k." and struggling for just spares, nevermind strikes. I must have been really on a few times though, when I scored really high and won and stayed consistent.

Now I know it was the science I was missing, on those times I could have done better, had I understood lane condition better and that it changes. And it explains why just slight changes in throw and approach I would try, could instantly change my game to good and I never understood why and it didn't make a whole lot of sense. Now it does.

I always thought it was funny when I would go to the bowling center to practice and the weekend warriors would look at me all weird as I walked in with 4 balls. Haha!! Were the lanes freshly oiled or dry? Did it rain that day or no? Never know what the lanes are going to be like. So you gotta make sure you have the right ball. It's funny too because I started bowling thinking I was just going to hang out with friends and get drunk. My best friend invited me to join his league team. I had no gear at all. So, I bought a ball, shoes, and some accessories. I never realized just how much money I would end up spending solely on bowling balls. $200+ per ball plus the cost of drilling? The sport adds up quick! I think at the peak, I had 6 balls. A core 3-4 of which I used during almost every match and the other 2-3 I only needed in very specific conditions, typically if I bowled at a different house with a different pattern or cold vs hot weather since the temp differences can be massive where I live.

But everything in this video is exactly what serious (not necessarily professional) bowlers analyze every single time they throw a ball. Where do you setup? Which slide pad are you going to use for this approach? What targeting system are you using? What board are you throwing at? What balls is everyone throwing? How is the oil movement of their balls going to impact the line that your ball takes? Are you staying ahead of the changes or are you chasing the lane? How many times do you have to ring the 10 pin before you'll stop being stubborn and make an adjustment? It's something that the people who say "Bowling isn't a support" just don't seem to understand. Like golf, bowling is a game of the mind.

Back somewhere around 1990, I had a ball with a symmetrical weight block shaped like a dumbbell, meaning almost all the weight was toward the surface on opposite sides.  It was a Brunswick Rhino.  I "believe" it was the red one, as I had both red and black Rhinos in my bags.  I had it drilled so the weights would rotate along my track (the way my ball rolled when I released it), maximizing the velocity of the heavy outer parts of the weight block.  That gave it a HUGE increase in inertia, much like a gyroscope.  It made it MUCH harder for the impact with the pins to deflect my ball.  My league-mates would watch in disbelief how well the ball would break, even on wet lanes, and how my light hits on the headpin would still carry through and take out the five pin, giving me strikes when I "should have" left pins standing.  I would say, on the average, it gave me 10-15 extra pins per game.  If you can EVER find a modern ball with such a weight block, buy it.  How you have it drilled makes ALL the difference, so make sure to put the weights parallel to your track.  You can find your track by rolling your dry ball down a freshly oiled lane, and looking at the wet circle made by the oil on the surface of the ball.  Generally, a "full roller" is considered the best, meaning the ball rolls along the largest part of the surface, centered on the space between your thumb hole and finger holes.  In my case, however, I threw a "semi-roller", meaning my track was diagonally above and to the right of the finger holes (top left to bottom right), and ran along a path about 90% of the diameter of the ball.  I only weighed about 145 lbs. dripping wet and threw the heaviest ball I could get (~16.2 lbs. before drilling, if I remember correctly), as I considered control and carry more important than velocity.  Why would it matter if I could throw it (a lighter ball) faster, if I couldn't hit where I was aiming and the ball wouldn't carry as well?

I was an avid bowler for many years starting in the 50s with pin boys.  I remember the first automatic pinsetters.  Once upon a time bowlers cheated by having "weighted balls". They gave an unfair advantage and were outlawed.  In the 60s and 70s I carried a 200+ average was considered turning professional. In 1980 I bowled a perfect 300 in a league that was 70 years old and they had never had a 300 game bowled. In a hall of 36 lanes filled with 5 man teams on each lane, when I was in the 9th inning the entire hall came to a silent halt to watch me finish.  It made the papers and It was sanctioned by the then ABC. Got a ring for my effort.  When I tell people how different the game is now they are incredulous to think that something as simple as bowling appears could be different.  When I tell them that perfect games are dime a dozen these days compared to when I achieved mine they wonder what's different?  Watch this amazing video.

A comment about the Radius of Gyration. A ball with a lower RG WILL allow you to put rotation into the ball more easily, as you said, but there is a cost. It also allows the ball to loose that spin energy more quickly as friction adds up during the hook phase. The end result is a curve that is more rounded and smooth than a higher RG ball (or finger hole drilling layout), which hooks later, but maintains that energy longer and therefore hooks more sharply.

it nice to understand that as a bowler since it can give you options to go to in your bowling bag, should the conditions favor one shape of curve over another.

So what is the next technological jump. I foresee a ball surface that changes based on what the ball is doing. If it is spinning rapidly across the oily part of the lane it has a coating that repels the oil to the point that it minimizes surface area touching the lane, then as it begins to grip the lane, the coating changes properties exposing micro needles that dig into the wood even more. Given that the outcome desired is set, the different means to reach the outcome can be experimented on endlessly meaning technology will continue to advance towards greater and greater efficiency. I also could imagine a ball with a motor inside it that spins the core to help increase the hook.

Very interesting video, but i have to correct you on the winter tire part.
Winter tires have bad traction in the summer not because of a surface finish but of the much lower viscosity which is a greatly temperature dependent figure. If the temperature drops too low summer tires will become hard and brittle and this leads to reduced surface contact. On the other side winter tires which are much softer will become even softer in hot surroundings, so soft that they start to wobble around on the road. Both are of course states with lower than ideal traction.

The weight blocks were really just tweaks to the way the ball hooks. What has made the most difference, by FAR in how much you can hook the ball is the material the ball is made of and the texture of the surface. (is is sanded or polished?)
In the old days, they were only made of hard rubber. Those only would hook so much. Then they came out with polyester (or plastic as we called them) and those were better in some cases.
Then in 1980, AMF introduced the first urethane ball, the Angle.
Not long after, Fab came out with the Hammer, and the race was on.
Urethane ball technology advanced through the 80's, but it only went so far.
But in the early 90's, they came out with reactive urethane, and that was a HUGE game changer. The biggest one we've ever had. The bowling centers had to add more oil because reactive balls gripped so well and hooked so much. If you took a reactive ball back in time and bowled on a 70's or 80's oil pattern, you wouldn't be able to keep it on the lane...it'd be like the dry lane in this video.
Then they expanded on this tech, but reactive urethane was the biggest leap ever, by far. Reactive gave much bigger hooks to people who used to be able to just barely hook it.

Along the way, the weight blocks were changing and certainly contributed to the tweaking of the shape of your shot, but the biggest change ever was reactive urethane. You can't put a fancy weight block in a plastic ball and make it hook like the pros, but you can put reactive resin on an old-timey weight block and it'll still hook like crazy.
It's kind of like the distances in golf. The biggest hitters today can't hit it any farther with yesterday's equipment than the biggest hitters of back then, but they crush it with the balls and clubs they use today.

As far as scores go, the oil pattern is what changed to allow more 300's and 800 series. That changed in the 80's, when they went to "short oil" patterns. Averages skyrocketed, and the number of perfect games was ridiculous. I remember when, where I'm from, there had been like 2-3 300 games EVER, then in the 80's there were multiple 300's each week. That certainly wasn't because the bowlers got better. You had older guys who were 180 lifetime average bowlers, suddenly averaging 210. The scratch bowlers, who previously averaged in the lower 200's, were up between 220-230.
That's not changed since. They could bring scores down with tougher oil patterns if they wanted to, but why would they? You'd probably have a mass exodus when all the bowlers who now average between 200-210 fell down to 160-170, and of course the bowling centers don't want that.

@Veritasium Why weight them by P-values? That doesn't make any sense. and I quote two of the most influential statisticians of the last century:

"Statistical significance is the least interesting thing about the results. You should describe the results in terms of measures of magnitude –not just, does a treatment affect people, but how much does it affect them. "

-Gene V. Glass1

"The primary product of a research inquiry is one or more measures of effect size, not P values. "

-Jacob Cohen

I may be understanding the P value being used here incorrectly, but if it is a parametric test of means used then the p value describes how likely you are to have found a particular set of observations if the null hypothesis were true. The null hypothesis here being that the specific factor tested does not influence probability of a strike. So why not use beta weights or b-values? The statistics of this study seem grossly inadequate. How were the points weighted? I know it isnt your paper and you need to get through it quickly, but as a data-oriented person... what is going on here? Am I just missing something or could they have done an analysis that better looks changes in probability of getting a strike more directly?

I worked in a bowling alley in the mid-60's as a teenager, the balls didn't have the off-set center weights back then and we didn't oil the alley's as much as today.  A 300 game was rare back then, front sports page big letter headlines.  Now those off set weights in a bowling ball make them hook way more.  People toss them faster, knowing they'll hook at the end.  So lane owners added more oil to protect the lanes.  It's a totally different game than 60 years ago.  And 300 games and very high scores are common today.   And the balls soak up so much oil now, they sometimes are overweight. Think of it like the super thin handle bats in baseball....which they changed, bats don't break as much now.
I want a custom ball that messes up the lane oil for other bowlers

I like the video about the technik vbehind the bowling. But there are some differences beside the older variants and the bowling you are talking about. We call the traditional bowling in germany 'kegeln', which is probadly very close to the one Martin Luther played. The balls don't have holes and they are smaller (lighter) that you can grip then with one hand. So you basically makes straigth throws.
The pins are also different usually you have pins attached to the automat with wires, and they are smaller and have different weigths which affects the behaviour after the hit. So there is a lot more behind 9 and 10 pin different.
The lane is wider.
You have just one shot, so no chance for a spare. Or you have to throw till every pins are down (there is a exception for pin 5), depending on the variant you are playing.
I like the US bowling more, but even when it looks similiar they are ver different in mechanic and gameplan so that you can call it to difference sports/games.

Fun fact "9 pin bowling" is pretty different from the ordinary bowling.

In Germany we call it "Kegeln" and the lane is different (smaller beginning and not lubricated), the balls are different (smaller and no holes) and just one shot per turn.

It's usually played in a cellar of a pub, there are multiple rulesets and drinking games and it is usually combined with huge amounts of alcohol.

I remember my dad telling me about when he was a pin boy at a local bowling place back in the 1930's. He was perched above the pins operating a mechanism that correctly placed the pins on pins that popped out of holes in the floor. After placing the bowling pins on the little spikes, he would release the pedal so that the pins would recess back flush into the floor and the bowler would send another ball down the lane.
The bowlers would tip the boys working the pins and the guys that knew how they worked would slip him some extra for some hidden help. If you timed it right, one could stomp on the pedal quickly to help knock over the ones that were teetering on the edge.
He told me he made some good money that summer.

I loved seeing more of the science. I knew most of this, because I grew up in a bowling alley. But seeing it broken down in such a detailed and easy to understand scientific way was intriguing!
As a homeschooled kid, I used to be a scorekeeper with the old cellophane score transparencies that displayed up on the wall before the TV screens. I would come in and spend 10-16hrs a day during the large tournaments/qualifiers. It made me good at math and earned a lot of money and free bowling games. It was a “non paying “ gig, but you earned tips especially if you knew how to work with the bowlers. Some liked to chat, others couldn’t stand to talk to anyone, some appreciated you cheering, others didn’t want any input. The bowling alley would “pay” us in free bowling passes and pizza slices at breaks, unlimited soda. I had so many passes I coulda kept bowling till I was 100.

I didn't see any mention of total ball weight as a potential factor in ball performance.
In days gone by I'd bowl a few games recreationally every couple of years. So selection of my rental ball was an adventure. I'd search the alley racks for a few with workable hole size and pattern. And take them to my lane for my games. Typically they'd vary in weight; sometimes quite a bit. People told me that a 16 pound ball gave more "pin action". But there was never enough consistency of factors or corresponding results to come to any conclusions.

for those watching and using a house ball good luck... a house ball doesn't hook it will go straight unless you are forcibly hooking it ... you can also hook it at a regular bowling alley but the lane " has to be used up " all the oil is mostly gone causing your ball to hook in the dry area twords the back... if you use a ball that has a core it will hook even earlier causing you to gutter .. Tips for Beginners buying their first ball and going to a local bowling alley if you want to bowl  and have fun and get strikes go in the morning or after a league game thats when fresh oil is applied ... if you go at night at most bowling alleys the oil is mostly all used up and you cant really have fun with your bought bowling ball that has a core

Am I the only one, the only person, to watch this video and think......... isn't that cheating? All this weighted ball nonsense and printing special oil patterns on the lane. And the balls aren't actually balls! A ball is, generally speaking, a sphere of consistent density all the way through. These ones are just bags of tricks, cheating machines, in a spherical casing. And why are the bowling alleys using oil-printers? Can't they just oil them evenly like a normal person would polish a wooden floor? And the floor, come to think of it, isn't even wood here! Composite of wood-dust and plastic resins.

Just seems like the "sport" has mutated, year by year, invention by invention, so now it's about choosing the right invention for the bowler, to compensate for the invention used by the bowling alley. Just WTF was wrong with a sphere made out of rubber, and a wooden floor?

Also that old dude, the bowler, seems to have a teeny bit of an "attitude" problem, and by "attitude" I mean it looks like cocaine. Would certainly de-boredom a game of bowling, but I dunno, some people's personalities are just like that anyway.

Great video! Who would think there were so many technologies hidden in a “simple” bowling game. The alleged need of oiled lanes baffles me, though. I used to play bowling at a sports club in the 80’s and 90’s. It wasn’t professional but the teams were fairly organized. What's interesting is that we used the same technique of rolling the ball to hit the pins sideways. But the lanes at the club didn't have any oil, much less oil patterns. We compensated for the “lack of slipness” by throwing the ball almost to the sides of the gutter. With enough force, the balls would travel about 2/3 of the lane length before the strong rolling motion took precedence and made the balls roll left (or right) at the proper angle for a strike. We may not have been world champions but our oiless technique worked pretty well.

In Germany bowling is actually something different than the version you mentioned before as the religious one. It's called "Kegeln" because the pins are called "Kegel". In this game you have 9 pins and a whole set of different rules eg for constellations you can knock down for different amount of points, it also allows for teamplay opposed to bowling. Another difference is that the balls aren't drilled and you rather roll them instead of them spinning on the lane. It's a more traditional sport mostly played by boomers the average age in a club is probably around 50 or more. The machines used are mostly older and simpler but quite similar to bowling ones. There are also completely analog versions of that, pretty much the way Martin Luther must have played it. I don't know if this is a thing outside of Germany but here it really is a known an renowned sport. (among boomers, ask Gen Z kids and probably most of them think "Kegeln" is equivalent to bowling)

Fascinating. I wonder what you would make of cricket. Typically bowlers will ensure the ball is bounced off the pitch before it reaches the batsman. Spin bowling is popular, which is aided by the bowler shining one half of the ball while leaving the other side rough. Bowlers will often look for defects in the pitch so they can aim to bounce the ball from that point to make the ball’s trajectory even more unpredictable for the batsman. It’s not permitted for a batsman to defend their wicket with their leg, so when a ball hits the batsman’s leg and it appears that otherwise the ball would have hit the wicket, the batsman can be given ‘out’ on the basis of ‘leg before wicket’. This is sometimes difficult for the umpire to judge, so in recent years they’ve developed technology which shows the trajectory of the ball if it hadn’t been interrupted. Of course, cricket is an outdoor game played on grass pitches, so it is highly affected by the condition of the pitch, the wind, temperature, moisture, etc.

Why would the bowling robot not throw a straight ball (in competition, I get that they want to test things so curve is preferred there). Curve is preferred for humans because it increases pin movement (due to angular inertia transfer) as well as the and "pocket" size, as described in the video. But a robot should be accurate enough to hit the perfect shot on a straight ball, eliminating the oil variance over time issue, and in theory, playing "perfectly". Us meatbags, on the other hand, can't quiiiite throw perfect enough to nail it as consistently as someone playing with the help that curve provides, so it makes sense why a lifetime of throwing curve allows us to make the minute adjustments necessary to keep hitting the right spot.

It would be a bit humiliating for a pro bowler to lose to a straight ball though.


I threw straight for most of my youth, as I was more consistent with it and I didn't have enough body mass to curve effectively. My dad has multiple 300's, but I hold two awards he has never managed to replicate: a triplicate (three games in a row of the same score), and a hilarious 319 score, due to the overly-generous handicap in the youth-adult league at the time. It is absolutely possible to get enough action to strike with a straightball, but we're not precise enough. A robot should be able to do that, and be unbeatable.

I was really into bowling when I was young, bowling in junior leagues and for a couple of years in adult leagues. Pete Weber was pretty new to pro bowling when I quit bowling. I spent a lot of time at the alleys back then and was there when Tim Roderick (I might have messed up his name a little, in which case I apologize to him) bowled the first 300 game in AJBC (American Junior Bowling Congress) sanctioned league play. I never had a perfect game. My best was 267, and I was very proud of that. There was talk about different weight blocks back then, but things have become a lot more sophisticated since I quit the game.

What I don't get is why they make the cores those crazy shapes. You could get any possible moment of inertia out of a rectangular prism. Are those weird shapes supposed to be easier to put in the right position, or easier to manufacture? Or is it just the result of superstition where bowlers think that a fancier core will have some effect?

I played club bowling with scores between upper 190s and up to 220s when I was in my teens. Highest score in a tournament was 270. Not good anough for anything more than club play. Back in the 80s the Lanes we played were made of wood, lane oiling was done by hand mop, and pin placement wasn't always consistent. The ball was the only consistent thing for the player. There were so many  variables and balls so ordinary in construction   that it was more like playing golf with the player having to learn the lane and all its attributes in the shortest time possible during tourneys.  Getting 300 even in the pro league was  a celebrated feat bec of these variables. After stopping for a decade or so I asked  a friend why people (even at lower levels) seemed to be hitting higher scores  and (at higher levels) 300 more often.  They said Synthetic lanes. Even machine oiling. Better pin machines. And the so called reactive balls with these customized cores. Short story, bowling seemed to have gotten "easier". I get the fun factor. And new tools in the box make for better watching. But it seems to me to take the old challenge out of it.  Ignore this. It's just an old bowlers rant.

When I was a kid, I couldn't hit anything with the more age-appropriate lighter weight balls at the alley, so I tried a heavier one meant for adults. I didn't really have the arm or wrist strength for it, so I accidentally started bowling back-hand. Without having to hold my arm rigid, just letting physics do the work for me, it was a lot easier, and I could impart whatever spin I wanted, except it had the weird artifact of having a LOT of backspin. More serious bowlers around me would scoff as my ball would practically ride the edge of the gutter, almost a gutter-ball but for one millimeter, and then get a shock when it hooked hard to the left at the end of the lane.

I'm pretty sure no pro bowlers would use a backhand style like that. It was just a quirk I accidentally developed as a kid.

You're representation of a perfect game at 5:42 is not correct sadly. The tenth frame is special. As you described, a strike allows the next 2 shots to count again. A spare only allows the next 1. In order for a perfect game, every frame's strike must be followed by 2 more to make an even 30 pins/frame. To compensate for this, the tenth allows for a follow-up to a maximum of 3 shots or 3 strikes. If you were to spare in the tenth however, you would only get one more shot whether you strike or not. If the first rack of pins is not all knocked down, meaning not a spare or strike at the beginning of the tenth frame, then no follow-up shots would be allowed. So for a perfect game, it should show a single strike in each frame 1-9, but 10 should show XXX. This totals to 30/frame or 300 total for the game.

Haven't bowled since the early 70s. The bowling alleys we had available were all built in the 1930s to 1960s. I never was any good at it. Just wasn't fun to lose all the time and my coordination was probably poor. By my teens, it was embarrassing to me that my mom was a much better bowler. So I stopped bowling because I was so bad at it. There were no weird cores in balls then. All lane floors were wood. They tried their best to manufacture slick surface symmetrical balls although later seemed to prefer surfaces with friction. Frankly, you bought a bowling ball then by whether you liked the color and how many finger holes it provided and by the weight wanted. The balls seemed to be like rock if they had high resistance or smooth slick surfaces if you wanted something really colorful. No plastics. There wasn't all those choices then.

My step dad on the other hand could bowl over 250 all the time and had several 300 games. He would do a few trial throws and change lanes if he didn't like his results. I remember when he bowled an under 200 game he would be moody for days. Him and mom were in leagues for a while. She had a light colorful slick ball and he had the heaviest they made then that felt like a rougher surface than hers but still smooth. I don't think the lanes got oiled ever then. I remember they would do some nightly waxing and the lanes were actually repaired or replaced once a month as the places would have to shut down for a few days to do it. They actually called it waxing the lanes so it might have been wax laid down not oil then. We all kidded him that he was playing heavy baseball more than bowling. He would throw the heavy ball so hard it would go about 15 feet straight out before starting to come down and would crash into the lanes and then the pins with so much force that they often would fly out of the pin area. He didn't seem to hook much till the very end of the travel. We used to say that he hit the pins with so much power they fell down in fear of him! LOL! There were many a dent in lanes that had to be fixed after my father finished up a tournament. While I considered a good score for me was if I could get one or two strikes a game and a score of over 100.

By the mid 1980s bowling alleys were going broke everywhere and closing their doors as it was expensive to keep them running with the low fees they charged per game. Also family outings were far less common and young people were more into arcades than rolling ball sports. Most proprietors made all their money on concessions, arcades and building custom balls while reducing their number of lanes by then. The adults would go bowling while the kids would be plugging quarters in the arcade machines. While its made a few come backs, it's never been as popular as it was prior to the early 1970s.

I think great bowlers back then would fail big time on the oiled lanes of today. And I think pros today would fail big time on the lanes then. There was little to no info at all out on how to actually bowl in the 1960s and 1970s. And most lanes in smaller towns were actually built 20 years or more earlier. Never was told that hooking the ball was going to make a difference. My goal was just to not gutter it and hit as close to center as possible. (We now know why I was such a bad bowler!) And lanes weren't oiled much at all then and I think they were only waxed. This was a very interesting video. I had no idea that the art of bowling had become so involved with so many scientific variables and material changes of both balls, lanes, lubricants. Great video!

Early in the video you point out the distance between the head pin and its neighbour and point out the margin for error for a straight shot from centre versus what the ideal spin shot can achieve. Later in the video you discuss the most influential factors that create variability into that spin shot strategy. As described, those factors do not appear to influence the consistency of a straight shot. It would stand to reason that if you had perfect consistency and accuracy (like a robot), would a straight shot be the superior strategy?

Following on from that, given the data you have, would it be possible to calculate the point at which a humans consistency would make either strategy have the same equivalent value? If so, once calculated do any of the human pro's have a consistency above that magic number? Be interesting to find out if any pros could actually up their game by reverting to the strategy they likely avoid because they consider it worse but no one has ever done the math to prove it?

Otherwise you're just gonna frustrate yourself and, if you're in a league, your team.

Great video, but there was one thing that didn't seem quite right.

At 24:11 (talking about why rougher bowling balls seem to have less friction on the dry section of the lane), the statement: "they also act as badly as winter tires on a clean road on a totally dry lane. They actually have less friction because their rougher exteriors mean that less surface area is touching the lane."

The thing that doesn't quite add up is that frictional force is not a function of surface area or relative velocity. So theoretically, any ball of the same surface material and mass has the same frictional force regardless of roughness (as long as it can still be approximated as a sphere). When it comes to tires the extra grip from added surface area is because the tread is able to "dig into" the ground more, adding traction but not friction. I don't think that the tire analogy quite fits.

My guess as to why the rougher ball hooks slower in the dry area is: When the rough ball is in the oiled section the extra traction pulls it to the side as observed, but also slows down the rotation of the ball by converting some angular velocity to translational velocity and heat. When it gets to the dry section the friction makes it transition from sliding to rolling but the rolling is slower than the smooth ball would be at the same point in the lane because the smooth ball would not have bled off as much energy in the oiled section.

I played enough games to know how to throw the ball to get a strike every single time. Now if only it was as easy as aiming with the HUD IRL haha. and btw i don't agree with the perfect shot line that you show in the video and the guy told you. It's more consistent to have the ball skid to less of an angle by being slightly on the outside of the middle arrow rather than slightly inside. If you throw fast enough with enough side rotation then it's gonna hit the pins by brushing against and pushing the front pin at the same time in the side pin of the second row into the third row, while your ball will split the other side of the third row. The third row will fall in a chain reaction to the second row of pins falling and the ball hit strongly. Hitting with more angle like shown in the video might be more practically consistent IRL though maybe. But it runs the risk of cutting too much from the side into the pins because of the strong curve, and if you do hit too much from the side the second row of pins will not create the chain reaction expected. Either your pin opposite of the ball will go straight for the side without hitting the pins behind it, or the ball will cut too much and not make the side it hits from fall. By going straighter, faster and hitting stronger with more spin creates the beautiful strikes we all think of where the pins connect fast together and even fly in the air with enough spin and force. The ball can go almost straight from the arrows to the roll area and the spin will make it turn sharply and go straight again at the perfect angle of a third hitting the front pin from the right and two thirds rolling through the side pin of the second row. it's less of an arc, more force and less chance to end up in the gutter. Controlling the spin and speed accurately is something I'm not capable of but I play like never irl.

The smaller surface area of snow tire contact patch isn't why they would have less traction at the limit on a dry road. Surface area of the contact area isn't in the equation for friction force, just the normal force and the coefficient of friction for that particular combination of materials. The most likely cause would be that the tread tends to be deeper with wider gaps between the tread that allows the tread to squirm and lose good contact.

After watching this video, I had questions I never knew were relevant answered (that the eleventh strike - the one you get as bonus for getting a spare or strike in last frame - isn't written in the tenth frame in official games 5:41), and given lots of new questions I never thought about.

ie. Why do lanes share ball-returns? Every single time I have bowled, there has been issues where the neighbouring lane starts using the ball I selected, either by mistake or from people too lazy to select a new ball being overeager and realizing their max-weight ball doesnt work when tired, or timid and noticing their light ball bouncing off the pins and that heavier balls gives strikes. Hadn't realized til now, but this could have easily been avoided had the place not built a y-shaped ball return, and instead gone with 2 parallel returns and a partitioner).
or Why have the return y-shaped at all (as opposed to a single track), the split usually doesn't have the ball go to the correct side anyway (which is why some ppl can mistakenly use the incorrect ball, even when they aren't just the impatient kind waiting near the ball-spitting maw)? Literally all it gives is more capacity, but that could have easily been done in other ways.

There are some alternative bowling forms here and there throughout the U.S. There's duck-pin bowling and candle-pin bowling. Both are three throws per frame instead of only two. Duck-pin bowling uses shorter and squatter version of normal pins, whereas candle-pin are pretty much tall wooden sticks. Candle-pin is funky because you don't clear the deadwood between each throw.

I learned to bowl with the old school spherical core balls. They do not perform the "magic trick" of curving, so I had to depend on power and aim to get strikes. Somehow I still managed to score consistently in the 220 range, and I only bowled on average, once a month for a year or two.  I threw a 16 pound ball, that was not polished, and I threw it in a straight line from the far right of the foul line to just right of the center of the headpin. My strikes were like explosions that sent all ten pins into the pit ahead of the ball.  Tome, there was nothing scientific about getting strikes. Brute force and good aim is all it takes. I often got strikes when my ball hit left of center also. The problem with these new "engineered" balls is, that if you miss your mark by 2 centimeters, you end up with low first ball pin counts.

@Veritasium , horrible explanation of the physics of bowling. You’re just repeating the marketing pitch of the bowling ball manufacturers.

For example, physics wise, there are only 2 phases of a rolling body: rolling without slip or rolling with slip.

The “skid hook roll” are jargons made up by people clueless about physics. USBC suppose to do a study to determine if the ball skid hook roll or hook skid roll. They did their measurement and it was not skid hook roll. So the project head told the programmer to fudge the data so that they can say it’s skid hook roll.

The ball manufacturers use that to make up reasons for buying their balls that have no basis in physics. Somehow, the lane is divided into 3rd; 20 ft of “skid”, 20 ft of “hook”, 20 ft of “roll” so that you need to buy numerous balls to “manage” these.

Another example of marketing with no basis in physics. A sphere with the same radius of gyration (RG) will roll that same — that’s the definition of RG.

And yet, the ball manufacturers will say that different core shape having the same RG will roll differently?? Thus you need to buy new balls every years.

The German "Bowling" is called "Kegeln" and is VERY different from bowling:
- There are many different "games" you can play in Kegeln, not just one specific game. Most of the games are team games, where one team plays against another, but some are one player against a whole group.
- The balls are typically smaller and sometimes they don't even have holes for fingers
- The lane is typically shorter and nowadays is rarely made of wood - mostly laminated.
- The lane is not oiled and therefore skidding of the ball is pretty much a guarantied fail. (As shown in the video)
- In most modern lanes, the pins("Kegel") are attached to a cord/line. The after a ball was rolled, all pins are pulled up by those cords/lines and then re-placed. That means, the left pin is always the same pin.
And those are just the differences, I remember of my head.

The funny thing is, that it is technically jut a matter of muscle memory to get a strike.
How do you stand? Where do you stand? How do you move? How much spin do you give the ball? If you miss the strike you can tweak yourself. Move a bit to the side and turn your body. Do you swing your arm in a straight line or have you wiggled around while throwing? When did you release the ball? To soon or to late. Maybe you can try to give the ball more or less spin. And than it is just a matter of repeating these little tweaks over and over again till you got it right.
True, it is also a question about how tired your body is i you can keep repeating your movements. The longer you play, the more likely are errors and mistakes. My luckiest game was with 4 strikes in a row and 5 in total. Sadly I don't play it enough and never got to this muscly memory state. But is is always fun nontheless.

Small correction.

Polished balls are better for longer patterns and rough balls are better for short patterns.

Polished balls hold their energy longer so they can still hook after the oil, and rough balls hook sooner which is good for short patterns since you throw the ball further out/closer to the gutter.
